Despite price increases, it doesn‚Äôt mean that the U.S. is currently in a housing bubble. History has shown that prices can rise quickly over the years and can stabilize ‚öñÔ∏è or even keep climbing.

Demand for urban housing üèôÔ∏è eventually returned, but also remained steady in the suburbs üå≥.

With inventory at all-time lows, renters and buyers faced prices 13% percent above pre-pandemic levels in the first half of 2021.
Did you move out or stay in a major city during the course of the COVID-19 pandemic?

Before the COVID-19 pandemic, Millennials preferred to stay in metropolitan cities üöï and rent. But the shift to WFH üíª had people re-evaluate their space and location needs.

As they searched for homes outside of cities, this  contributed to the rise in suburban house prices.

When supply and demand eventually realigned, the bubble burst caused prices to fall 34% üìâ by 2012.

It left households with mortgage debts far above valuations. Sellers were left with properties üèöÔ∏è that were valued far less than anticipated.

With so many people looking to buy homes, a building boom üí• happened across larger states where plenty of land was available for construction.

This created an overabundance in supply and homes were sometimes priced much higher than the cost of land and construction üöß.

But sometimes housing costs can increase more rapidly ‚¨ÜÔ∏è. 

It‚Äôs estimated that housing prices have nearly tripled since the 1950s ‚Äì even after adjusting for inflation.

During the Global Financial Crisis, the initial rapid increase in prices caused a housing bubbleüéà.

Home prices and rents tend to move along with overall inflation. If the average price of goods, services, wages, and business üíº costs rise rapidly, home üè° prices and rents will too. 

Have you purchased a home in the last year?

Supply and demand ultimately determine house prices, but there are additional factors that can affect the market:
üèóÔ∏è Cost of building
üë∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏èLabor
üè¶ Interest rates
üìà Inflation

After a volatility spike, the market eventually does find stability ‚öñÔ∏è, situations resolve, and people gain a better understanding of the economic environment.

Unpack more investment banking terms here: https://t.co/0LJnxMa3AN

On the other hand, heightened volatility can also cause bull markets üêÇ (prices to rise).

During the 1990s dot-com bubble, volatility rose alongside stock prices. The growth expectations placed on the exciting but untested technology üíæ gave rise to increased uncertainty.
The VIX recorded the three biggest spikes ‚ö° in 1987, 2008, and 2020 where the negative feedback loop and reduced investor holdings caused a bear market üêª (prices to fall) each time.

When the VIX reaches high levels of uncertainty, fewer investors are willing to trade. 

Liquidity drops, volatility rises, and a negative feedback loop üîÅ is created.

To assess the level of risk in the market üèõÔ∏è, investors commonly use a market-wide volatility gauge called the VIX. 

It indicates expectations of volatility over the next month ‚Äì based on the prices of options on the S&P 500 Index üìà.

A state of heightened market volatility results from two key drivers:

üåéMacro uncertainty is how difficult it is for the market to value assets

üíßLack of liquidity is how easy it is to buy or sell an asset without affecting its market price

Volatility measures the variability of returns over time üóìÔ∏è and is considered a riskier investment.

The more uncertainty‚ùìthere is about an asset‚Äôs value, the more the price fluctuates.
Volatility is a measurement of price movement üìä for an asset, such as a stock, option, or bond. It describes an asset‚Äôs potential to rise or fall from its current price üí≤.

üè¶ Data APIs automatically retrieve information, like account balances 
üí≥ Process APIs trigger a service, like initiating a payment

So, what‚Äôs next for the Middle Office?  

Technology üíª will continue to play a crucial role in helping the function navigate investment complexity and volume, and in providing sharper insights üí°that help investment decision-making.

Constraints like market changes üìà üìâ, regulatory requirements, increased technology ‚ö°Ô∏è and staffing, and more complex assets have made it harder to run Middle Office operations in-house. 

Many investment managers are considering outsourcing to a provider with more capabilities.

Today the Middle Office has 5 main responsibilities once a trade takes place: 

1Ô∏è‚É£ Confirm the details with all participants 
2Ô∏è‚É£ Oversee trade settlements 
3Ô∏è‚É£ Track the asset 
4Ô∏è‚É£ Reconcile digital records 
5Ô∏è‚É£ Manage investment data

This new digital market meant that investors, brokers, and investment managers had to maintain and compare their own records to verify transactions. 

This oversight was the beginning of what would become the Middle Office.

In 1971, Nasdaq launched the first fully electronic stock exchange that allowed participants to:
‚úÖ Confirm trades
üîÑ Transfer money
üñ•Ô∏è Record stock ownership
As financial markets developed and became safer for investors through regulation, trading volumes reached levels üìà that made it hard to support physical exchanges.

Today, trading is done electronically ‚Äì with enormous volumes moving through the global markets every day üåé. 

This is where the Middle Office comes in.

In the earliest days of the stock market, a trade was an exchange between two people of physical money üíµ for physical stock certificates üìÉ. 

Since the trade was visible, each person‚Äôs assets could be easily verified ‚úÖ.

‚ÄúMiddle Office‚Äù is a common financial term you‚Äôve likely heard - and while it may sound like somewhere you go, it isn‚Äôt a physical location. 

Instead, it represents what happens after a trade is made.
